Award.AwardTitle: NSF East Asia and Pacific Summer Institute for FY 2012 in China
Award.AbstractNarration:
This action funds Kyana Young of University of Wisconsin - Madison to conduct a research project, entitled "Detection of Harmful Disinfectants Caused by Water Treatment" during the summer of 2012 at Sun Yat-Sen University in Guangzhou, Guangdong, China. The host scientist is Dr. Yang Xin.

The Intellectual Merit of the research project lies in understanding and mitigating risks as a result of inadequate treatment of water where and when an established water infrastructure is unavailable, for example, post war and post natural disaster situations.

A point-of-use treatment device that uses a photoelectrocatalytic oxidation (PECO) method can generate chlorine to purify water. However, when treating natural water which contains naturally-occurring organic matter (NOM) and heavily contaminated water to provide drinking water, disinfection by-products (DBP) must be monitored to ensure that potentially harmful chemicals are not produced or do not remain in the drinking water. In this research, raw water samples from five regions in China are being treated with the treatment device and tested for the presence of DBPs formed during treatment. Analytical techniques include gas chromatography and membrane introduction mass spectrometry.

Broader Impacts of an EAPSI fellowship include providing the Fellow a first-hand research experience outside the U.S.; an introduction to the science, science policy, and scientific infrastructure of the respective location; and an orientation to the society, culture and language. These activities meet the NSF goal to educate for international collaborations early in the career of its scientists, engineers, and educators, thus ensuring a globally aware U.S. scientific workforce.

POR.DRECONTENT:
As a fellow of the 2012 East Asia and Pacific Summer Institute (EAPSI), I had the opportunity to conduct water treatment/quality research at Sun Yat-Sen University in Guangzhou, China. The principal investigator (PI), Dr Xin Yang, invited me to contribute to an existing project, while helping to facilitate forward progress of the project. My project specifically focused on the use of ultra violet rays, supplemented with hydrogen peroxide, to use as drinking water treatment option for water contaminated with pharmaceuticals and personal care products (PPCP).

Water quality has become a challenging mandate to follow, as the contaminants found in drinking water are detected at limits previously not measurable. The current water infrastructure systems are neither designed to detect nor treat pharmaceuticals. Between 2006 and 2007, the Applied Research and Development Center of the Southern Nevada Water Authority, analyzed source water, treated drinking water, and distribution tap water for 51 pharmaceutical compounds.  While these compounds were detected in the water, their concentrations were measured in the 10-9g/L range. Evidence of consumption of these contaminants at such low concentrations has not been fully explored for their detrimental impact to humans.

For my research in China, I analyzed the use of ultraviolet rays and hydrogen peroxide to remove specific PPCPs from drinking water. Each experimental sample was prepared by adding a pre-determined concentration of a PPCP, along with hydrogen peroxide, sodium chloride, sodium bromide in a Petri dish. The dish was then exposed to a UV source, with buffer added to achieve a desirable pH. Samples, containing the PPCP of the Petri dish are extracted through a sterile syringe, at 0, 2, 5, 10, 20, 35, 50, 65, and 80 minutes time steps. The sample is then pressed through a microfilter, to remove any residual salts. Samples are then placed in a clear glass vial and analyzed using high performance liquid chromatography (HPLC), where the data is analyzed for degradation of the targeted PPCP over time. 

While I spent a considerable time in the laboratory, I also had the opportunity to travel to Beijing, Shanghai, Foshan, Qinyuan, and Tongli during my stay.  Having the experience to travel throughout China and visit the Great Wall, Tianamen Square, the Summer Palace, the Bund, all gave me the opportunity to gain a greater appreciation for Chinese language, culture, food, and social structure. This experience also allowed for me to nurture personal bonds with my lab mates and advisor in Guangzhou. I look forward to future collaborative endeavors with Professor Yang, Sun Yat-Sen University, and China as a whole. This experience allowed me the opportunity to embrace a culture different from my own, all the while helping me to mature as a person and a graduate student.   This opportunity should be afforded to those who are interested in international research, and for those who are open to challenging and rewarding experiences in their personal and academic lives.
